places.name: Pacific Ocean
places.description: The largest and deepest of Earth's five oceans.

persons.name: Ovid
persons.description: Roman poet who lived during the reign of Augustus.

persons.name: Plato
persons.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

persons.name: Plato

He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

persons.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
persons.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

persons.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
persons.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

persons.name: RichardKirwan
persons.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

persons.name: WilliamWhiston
persons.description: English (unorthodox) theologian, historian, natural philosopher, and mathematician. A leading figure in promoting the ideas of Isaac Newton whom he succeeded as Lucasian Professor.

persons.name: Gottfried WilhelmLeibniz
persons.description: A German polymath active as a mathematician, philosopher, scientist and diplomat who invented calculus

persons.name: Charles FrancisGreville
persons.description: A British antiquarian, collector and politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1774 to 1790. FRSL.

persons.name: Jacques Louis deBournon
persons.description: French born mineralogist who lived and worked in London. An Annual Subscribed to the Royal Institution, he was founder member of the Geological Society. FRSL.

persons.name: André-Jean-François-Marie Brochant deVilliers
persons.description: French mineralogist and geologist.

persons.name: ThomasThomson
persons.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

persons.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
persons.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

places.name: Freiberg
places.description: A university and former mining town in Saxony, Germany

persons.name: Rene JustHauy
persons.description: Hauy was a French priest and mineralogist. He helped to establish the metric system.

persons.name: René JustHaüy
persons.description: French priest, crystallographer and mineralogist who wrote the five volume Traité de minéralogie (1801). ForMemRSL.

persons.name: RobertJameson
persons.description: Scottish geologist and Regius Professor of Natural History at the University of Edinburgh. FRSL.

persons.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

persons.name: JohnMayow
persons.description: Cornish physiologist and chemist, investigated respiration especially. FRSL.

places.name: Sligo
places.description: The town of Sligo, in the north of Ireland, straddles the Garavogue River where it meets Sligo Bay.

places.name: Leicestershire
places.description: A county in the East Midlands of England.

places.name: Saxony
places.description: A state in eastern Germany.

places.name: Mountsorrel
places.description: Mountsorrel is a village in Leicestershire bordering the Charnwood Forest, an upland area with isolated outcrops of ancient Precambrian igneous rocks.

places.name: Alps
places.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

places.name: Wicklow
places.description: County Wicklow is a county in Ireland on the east coast, south of Dublin.

places.name: Mayo
places.description: A county in the west of Ireland

places.name: Charnwood Forest
places.description: The Charnwood Forest is a upland area in Leicestershire, the highest point being 278m. The geology is remarkable as Precambrian igneous rocks, some of the oldest rocks on earth, are seen as isolated outcrops, as in Davy's sketch.

places.name: Donegal
places.description: Donegal is a town at the mouth of the River Eske, in north-west Ireland.

places.name: Cornwall
places.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

places.name: Siberia
places.description: a vast Russian province encompassing most of Northern Asia, with terrain spanning tundra, coniferous forest and mountain ranges

persons.name: RobertJameson
persons.description: Scottish geologist and Regius Professor of Natural History at the University of Edinburgh. FRSL.

persons.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
persons.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

persons.name: Alexander vonHumboldt
persons.description: German geographer, naturalist and explorer. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Déodat Gratet deDolomieu
persons.description: French geologist. The rock, and region of the Alps, dolomite was named after him.

persons.name: Horace Bénédict deSaussure
persons.description: Genevan geologist, meteorologist, physicist, mountaineer and Alpine expolorer. Often referred to as the founder of Alpinism and modern meteorology.

places.name: Alps
places.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

persons.name: RichardKirwan
persons.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

persons.name: JohnPlayfair
persons.description: Professor of Natural Philosophy at Edinburgh University. His Illustrations of the Huttonian Theory of the Earth (1802) gave strong support to James Hutton's theory of uniformitarianism. FRSL.

persons.name: JamesHutton
persons.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

places.name: Edinburgh
places.description: The capital city of Scotland.

persons.name: JohnPlayfair
persons.description: Professor of Natural Philosophy at Edinburgh University. His Illustrations of the Huttonian Theory of the Earth (1802) gave strong support to James Hutton's theory of uniformitarianism. FRSL.

persons.name: JamesHall
persons.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

persons.name: JamesHutton
persons.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.
